user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 is: Language extensions should not be used.
You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of named_thread_starter:
```c
static MHD_THRD_RTRN_TYPE_ MHD_THRD_CALL_SPEC_
named_thread_starter (void *data)
{
  struct MHD_named_helper_param_ *const param =
    (struct MHD_named_helper_param_ *) data;
  void *arg;
  MHD_THREAD_START_ROUTINE_ thr_func;

  if (NULL == data)
    return (MHD_THRD_RTRN_TYPE_) 0;

  MHD_set_cur_thread_name_ (param->name);

  arg = param->arg;
  thr_func = param->start_routine;
  free (data);

  return thr_func (arg);
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
MHD_THREAD_START_ROUTINE_ thr_func;
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 1.2 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation in this fragment: 'MHD_THREAD_START_ROUTINE_ thr_func;' is just the use of a type name (presumably a typedef) and by itself does not use any compiler language extension. (If the underlying definition of MHD_THREAD_START_ROUTINE_ used a compiler-specific extension — e.g. a calling-convention or attribute such as __stdcall, __attribute__((...)), WINAPI, etc., explicitly documented as an extension — then that definition would violate MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2.)
